awd_titl_txt: Build and Broaden: Build and Broaden Indigenous Agriculture and Food Sovereignty Symposium
awd_abstract_narration:
The Build and Broaden Indigenous Agriculture and Food Sovereignty Symposium will provide opportunities for researchers, practitioners and community members to share common interests in the field of Indigenous agriculture and foods. Content of the symposium will be focused on four major themes in the area of Indigenous foods: ecology, economy, diversity, and sovereignty. Symposium attendees will view presentations, engage in discussions, and participate in hands-on demonstrations regarding Indigenous foods. Sovereignty is defined as self-governance, authority, jurisdiction and agency, thus Indigenous food sovereignty means Indigenous people have the authority, agency and ability to define what is food, how food should be grown, cared for, harvested, processed, consumed, and related to. As Indigenous people everywhere struggle yet persevere in redefining all their relationships, this relationship to the plant and animal worlds is key to deepening the ancient relationships all people have to their ancestral and adopted foods. This project will help bring these newly defined relationships to all the people living across Turtle Island (North America) through its objectives and outcomes, including proceedings. 
 
Indigenous foods are under-researched in our society, and as such, only scant evidence exists regarding contemporary scholarly work in this area. Symposia like this are vital to the collective understanding of the relationships between humans and food in general, and Indigenous foods specifically. It is estimated that currently, only five of the regularly occurring events focused on food studies across the nation are focused on Indigenous foods. Given the unique status of American Indian tribes in the US, it is important to develop a shared understanding of sovereignty in relation to food and food systems. Lastly, the relationship between traditional ecological knowledge (TEK) and scientific ecological knowledge (SEK) in relation to Indigenous foods, although little studied, has the potential to address food insecurity worldwide. TEK and SEK studies of Indigenous foods are both core to addressing world food shortages, health and nutrition, and Indigenous/non-Indigenous rights.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Indigenous agriculture and food sovereignty is currently under-researched in our society, and as such, only scant evidence exists regarding contemporary scholarly work in this area. However, as a growing interdisciplinary field, the Build and Broaden Indigenous Agriculture and Food Sovereignty Symposium brought together diverse practitioners and scholars directly engaged to exchange and bridge Indigenous and Western knowledges on agriculture and food systems. The open access Symposium Program is a resource for our network and others to make new connections to Indigenous and non-Indigenous scholars and scholarship more widely. Currently in progress, we are compiling and synthesizing Indigenous teachings and scholarship from the Symposium event to provide support and guidance on interdisciplinary food systems research, practices and partnerships. We expect the Proceedings document to be completed, and shared widely, in the summer of 2023.

To Build and Broaden Indigenous Agriculture and Food Sovereignty requires the active participation and engagement across diverse entities, including education, scholars, practitioners, producers, everyday community members, and other agriculture and food businesses of many kinds. The primary broader impact of the Build and Broaden Indigenous Agriculture and Food Sovereignty Symposium was building and broadening participation and engagement of peoples (scholars, students, practitioners, and students) who are currently underrepresented in STEM. For the Virtual sampler Symposium, 77 participants in total engaged in the event in September 2021. For the In-person Symposium event at the Keweenaw Bay Indian Community (KBIC) (Baraga MI) and in Marquette MI, we engaged participants at KBIC (150 persons) and in Marquette (332 persons) for a total of 482 participants in person. Over the course of the three days in-person Symposium, 31 sessions in total were conducted, including 19 outdoor demonstrations and engagement sessions (Tourist Park, Marquette MI) and 12 indoor conference sessions (NMU Center, Marquette MI). Invited guest presenters (virtual and in person) shared progress, approaches, and outcomes of food research studies, with broader Symposium themes in food ecology, economy, diversity, and sovereignty relationships. Invited presenters and guests also engaged in practical, hands-on demonstrations with conference attendees. The Build and Broaden network strengthened beyond our expectations, of food and agricultural sovereignty scholars and practitioners, Indigenous chefs and food producers, and students and community members throughout the Great Lakes region and beyond. The 3-day Symposium brought together presenters and demonstrators, primarily of Indigenous ethnicity, that included 91 scholars and practitioners from approximately 55 different organizations (e.g., education, government, law, and business) and diverse regions in the Americas. 

The Build and Broaden Indigenous Agriculture and Food Sovereignty Symposium project grant (2020-2022) outcomes were the successful planning and implementation of two Symposium events in 2021 and 2022, and also, the growth and strengthening of a network of agriculture and food sovereignty scholarship, practices, and relationships among each other across North America and beyond. The leadership team, supported by a Symposium committee, successfully organized and implemented a virtual 2-day symposium Sampler event (September 2021), and a 3 day onsite symposium May 20-22, 2022 in Marquette, Michigan and Baraga/L’Anse, Michigan. The community hosts for the events were Northern Michigan University, City of Marquette, Michigan, and the Keweenaw Bay Indian Community, along with many supporting organizations and institutions. During a cool and wet late May along Lake Superior, the Food Sovereignty Symposium and Festival brought together several hundred individuals from across North America to celebrate and educate each other in ways of living, learning, knowing, and feeding communities using local, regional and culturally significant foods (plants, animals, and fungi) in culturally sensitive practices and ways, prepared by teams of Indigenous chefs guided/supported by the leadership team. The in-person Symposium also provided an opportunity for presenters, chefs, and other teachers to share knowledge in the form of presentations, culinary dishes, and hands-on tool workshops. Given the preceding two years of pandemic restrictions on social interaction, the event was an important opportunity for reconnection. For planning team members who organized or participated in previous events, witnessing the post-pandemic growth in knowledge and skillsets was impressive. Other building and broadening entities connected with our network included Native American, federally recognized Tribes such as the Keweenaw Bay Indian Community, Sault Ste. Marie Tribe of Chippewa Indians, and the Bay Mills Indian Community. Some Business/Organizations engaged are Wild Bearies, Native American Food Sovereignty Alliance (NAFSA), Gatherings Cafe, and Yawekon Foods. Participating Michigan Colleges/Universities include Northern Michigan University, Ferris State University, Michigan Technological University, Keweenaw Bay Ojibwa Community College, Michigan State University Extension, Oakland State University, and Bay Mills Community College as well as the University of Wisconsin-Madison. Many partners in this network continue to remain engaged with each other which we expect will lead to additional diverse and inclusive strategies and (re)solutions as well as building and strengthening equitable food system networks, and research and education relationships, more widely.
